Subject: NEAT for HMMs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=282483363; y=8q8e1zFaxl3U5lCfSChe6mdBuFmH5BsNbOoiLwnqO83dpy8

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hello,

I'm planning this semester to investigate the applicability of the NEAT
algorithm to the evolution of Hidden Markov Models.  I'm getting a PhD in
Bioinformatics, and HMMs have many applications to biological sequence
analysis.  The HMMs used are currently built by hand and can be quite
complex, and though there has been some successful research into evolving
them, none that I know of has attempted to take advantage of NEAT's bag o'
tricks.

HMMs are very similar structurally to neural networks, and my suspicion is
that many of the same pathologies that confound the evolution neural
structures apply to HMMs.  If I'm right, then NEAT seems like a very
attractive solution.  I'm hoping that I can use the NEAT algorithm almost in
it's entirety, since almost everything seems applicable to this domain (and
I believe Ken has said that NEAT can be thought of as a general structure
evolving algorithm, rather than being specific to ANNs).

The first step is sorting out exactly what the canonical version of NEAT is.
 My plan is to use Ken's dissertation as the primary reference.  Is this
wise?  Or have there been advances in the intervening years that I ought to
know about?  For instance, one nuance that a colleague of mine at UT
mentioned is SharpNEAT's periodic decomplexification phase.  He suspects
this phase is quite useful, even though it is not part of the original NEAT
spec.  What do you guys think?

Ken, if you were to set one of your students to the task of writing their
own NEAT from scratch, which resources would you point him/her to?

Daniel

--000e0cd71eca5d9342047a80abe7

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
